msIdentifier.collection: Civil War & Reconstruction Governors of Mississippi, Main Collection

note.p: William Lewis Sharkey served as Mississippi’s governor in 1865, early in the Reconstruction era.

Born in Sumner County, Tennessee, on July 12, 1798, Sharkey moved with his family to Warren County, Mississippi, in 1804. As an adult, he studied law and began practicing in Natchez, Mississippi, in 1822. Sharkey moved to Vicksburg in 1825 and pursued political office. He won election to the Mississippi House of Representatives and served one term from 1828 to 1829.

In 1832, Sharkey married Minerva Cage, a widow with two children. The couple had four children over the next several years. In 1832, Sharkey also became a circuit court judge and was shortly thereafter elected to the High Court of Errors and Appeals, the predecessor to the Supreme Court of Mississippi. He served in that role for 18 years, resigning in 1851. From there, he took a diplomatic appointment for the United States government, serving as U.S. Consul in Havana, Cuba, until 1854. After completing that diplomatic assignment, Sharkey returned to Mississippi and returned to legal and political duties, helping compile the Mississippi Code of 1857.

During the secession crisis in the winter of 1860 and 1861, following Abraham Lincoln’s election, Sharkey remained a steadfast Unionist. Having been a member of the Whig Party, he retained his opposition to secession and refused to support the Confederacy, even as he remained in Mississippi through the Civil War. Despite his political stance against Mississippi’s secessionist government, Confederate officials left him alone out of respect of his past service to the state as a judge and legal scholar.

After the Confederacy’s defeat, President Andrew Johnson appointed Sharkey provisional governor of Mississippi in June 1865. In that role, he called forth a constitutional convention to meet Johnson’s goal of swiftly restoring former Confederate states to the Union. In October 1865, Benjamin Humphreys won election as Mississippi’s governor. Sharkey did not vacate the office, though, until December 1865, having served less than a year. Although no longer governor, Sharkey was selected by the Mississippi legislature to serve in the U.S. Senate. Federal officials denied him a seat, and the rest of the Mississippi congressional delegation, following the Republican backlash to Mississippi’s Black Codes—a set of racially discriminatory laws passed by the Mississippi legislature in 1865.

Having been denied a U.S. Senate seat, Sharkey returned to practicing law, in Jackson, Mississippi. He died in Washington, D.C., on March 30, 1873, and is buried at Greenwood Cemetery in Jackson, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; David Sansing, “William Lewis Sharkey: Twenty-fifth Governor of Mississippi: June to December 1865,” Mississippi History Now; FindaGrave)

person.persName: Claiborne, J. F. H. (John Francis Hamtramck), 1809-1884

note.p: John Francis Hamtramck Claiborne was a Mississippi politician and historian in the nineteenth century.

Born on April 24, 1809, in Natchez, Mississippi, Claiborne was educated in Virginia and became a practicing attorney in Mississippi in 1825. He entered state politics, serving in the Mississippi House of Representatives from Natchez from 1830 to 1834. He was then elected to the U.S. House of Representatives, and served from 1835 to 1838. After leaving Congress, Claiborne returned to Natchez and became editor of the Mississippi Free Trader.

In 1842, Claiborne received an appointment to the Choctaw Claim Commission, established to distribute land received by Mississippi from the Treaty of Dancing Rabbit Creek. His position on the commission was reportedly made by two other members to provide him 32,000 acres of former Choctaw land to pay off a debt. The deal failed, though, and a public feud erupted. Claiborne was removed from the commission and he moved to New Orleans, Louisiana.

In 1853, Claiborne was appointed a U.S. timber agent in Louisiana and Mississippi. During the Civil War, he remained at home, determined to stay out of the conflict. He intentionally avoided politics for most of his life afterwards. Claiborne spent most of his time after the Civil War as a prolific writer, producing several historical articles and books, including a history of Mississippi. He eventually returned to Natchez and died on May 17, 1884. He was married to Martha Dunbar and had at least three children that lived to adulthood. Claiborne is buried in Natchez City Cemetery in Natchez, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave; Franklin L. Riley, “Life of Col. J. F. H. Claiborne,” Mississippi Historical Society)
John Francis Hamtramck Claiborne belonged to the following social groups:
Located in south Mississippi, Hancock County was established on December 18, 1812 from Mobile County, Alabama. (Mississippi Encyclopedia; Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

gloss.p: A person who performs "an official examination of the information that a person or a business provides to the tax authority to check that it is accurate and legal." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Someone whose job is to collect taxes for the government. The term is often used to refer to the tax authorities." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who is in charge of a trial in a court and decides how a person who is guilty of a crime should be punished, or who makes decisions on legal matters." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A public officer who judges local and less important legal cases, and performs marriage ceremonies." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Individuals responsible for enforcing laws in designated areas." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"An official in a town or village having some of the responsibilities of a police officer." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"In the U.S., an official whose job is to be in charge of performing the orders of the law courts and making certain that the laws are obeyed within a particular county." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who works in an office, dealing with records or performing general office duties." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"An official organization whose job is to manage a particular activity, suggest laws related to the activity, and make certain that laws are obeyed" concerning law enforcement. (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A place where trials and other legal cases happen, or the people present in such a place." (Cambridge Dictionary)
A court of law for "the legal process of deciding if a person's will has been made correctly and if the information it contains is correct." (Cambridge Dictionary)

element.label: Description
element.value: From the Mississippi Department of Archives and History Governor Sharkey Collection. Petition from citizens of Hancock County, Mississippi, to Mississippi Governor William L. Sharkey, recommending individuals to the positions of judge of the probate court, clerk of the circuit and probate courts, sheriff, and tax collector and assessor.

div.p: To his Excellency William L. Sharkey Governor of the State of Mississippi.

The Undersigned Citizens of the County of Hancock and State of Mississippi aforesaid, beg leave to recomend to your excellency, as Suitable persons in these times to hold the following offices in Said County
For Judge of Probates William Wirmingham former incumbent before the war

" [gap] Clerk of the Circuit and Probate Courts David W. Johnston former deputy clerk
[gap] the former incumbent John S. Bradford being removed from the County
for Sheriff Tax Collector & assessor Napoleon Monet, former incumbent
" [gap] Member of Board of County Police District No 5 Elihu Carver former incumbent
" [gap] Justices of the peace for " [gap] " [gap] " [gap] James Johnston " [gap] "

Respectfully &c.
R. Euger
John V Tonemé
John Martin
E. T. Saucier
E Garaudy
John. H. Nicholson
I fully concur in the above. The persons recommended, and those who have recommended them, are the most trust-worthy, substantial and intelligent men in the county.

Citizens of Hancock
Recommending Suitable Candidates for County Officers
